An A-module M is called a free A-module if it has a basis, i.e., a free system of generators. In this case, every element x in M admits a representation x = sum_{i in I} a_i x_i with coefficients a_i in A that are unique.
The residue class module M/N of an A-module M by a submodule N is defined analogously to the quotient space in vector spaces, where M/N consists of the cosets of N in M.
Does the concept of a/an Free A-module need to be defined for a definition of a/an Residue class module to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The concept of a Free A-module is not necessary for defining a Residue class module. The definition of a Residue class module involves taking an A-module M and a submodule N, and forming the set of cosets of N in M. This concept is analogous to the quotient space in vector spaces and does not inherently require that M be a free A-module. A free A-module is defined as having a basis, which allows every element to be uniquely represented as a linear combination of basis elements. However, the definition of a Residue class module only requires the existence of an A-module and a submodule, without any stipulation that the A-module must be free. Therefore, the concept of a Free A-module is not a prerequisite for understanding or defining a Residue class module.
